name: Basic Monitoring
content:
The majority of patients in critical care areas require invasive blood pressure monitoring. It is the gold standard of blood pressure measurement, giving accurate beat-to-beat information. The steps are as follows:

  • A short cannula is inserted into an artery, typically the radial, femoral or dorsalis pedis artery. The cannula is connected to a transducer via a stiff non-compliant tubing containing saline
  • The column of saline moves with the arterial pulsation and the transducer converts this movement to electrical energy
  • A numerical and graphical display allows beat-to-beat measurement of pressure. It also allows analysis of the waveform, which can be clinical observation of swing or a computerized pulse contour analysis, for example, the PICCO or LiDCO system

Some complications of Invasive blood pressure monitoring: 

  1. Bleeding
  2. Infection
  3. Haematoma
  4. Air embolism
  5. Thrombosis
  6. Distal limb ischaemia or infarction
  7. Inadvertent intra-arterial drug injection
  8. Damage to local structure, for example, nerves

Damping can interfere with the interpretation of invasive blood pressure.  Overdamping lowers the systolic pressure and elevates the diastolic pressure and seems to 'flatten the trace'.
